Award.AwardTitle: Designing a System for Improved Null Results Tracking: Berkeley, CA - December 2019

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for a workshop on "Designing a System for Improved Null Results Tracking," to be held in December 2019 in conjunction with the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences Annual Meeting. The workshop will focus on the design of a sustainable, integrated, and multi-stakeholder system for improving the monitoring of and access to outputs from all funded research. Research projects that yield null findings are less likely to be published, yet still may serve as a valuable resource to both the public and the research community. While several mechanisms have begun to emerge to address this problem, these approaches tend not to be coordinated, and many institutions lack the capacity to adopt them. This workshop will convene an interdisciplinary group of research stakeholders to discuss existing and new approaches for improving the tracking of funded research outputs, with special consideration for projects that yield null results. The academic community, policymakers, and the public at large would benefit from more complete access to research results. Products for the broader community include recordings of live-streamed presentations, presentation slides, and a report synthesizing the workshop's proceedings and conclusions.

This workshop will explore integrated approaches for addressing the inter-related problems of publication bias, questionable research practices, and the file drawer problem (where unpublished null or unexpected results remain locked away in researchers' file cabinets) in the social and health sciences. These problems can lead to incomplete and biased bodies of knowledge. Emphasis will be placed on striving for simplicity, lowering barriers to uptake of existing and new approaches, and avoiding high transaction costs for researchers and funders, as well as on ensuring compatibility with the values of scientific integrity and public interest. The event will begin with a discussion of design failures in how science is currently organized in research funding agencies and other institutions in order to build consensus within the group on priority issues to be addressed. Subsequent presentations and discussions will center on topics such as the effectiveness of study registries, the implementation of results repositories, how the benefits of reporting null results could be increased or the costs reduced, and strategies for research community monitoring of unreported results from registered studies. Participants also will deliberate about how such a system could feasibly be implemented and tested.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On December 12, 2019, the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences (BITSS) with leadership and support from PI Edward Miguel and David Laitin of Stanford University?s Immigration Policy Lab (IPL) held a one-day workshop titled ?Unlocking the File Drawer.? The meeting was organized in response to growing recognition of the barriers to publication of non-significant results and concerns over publication bias, or the skewing of published research results towards those that are positive or statistically significant. The workshop convened stakeholders from academic research including those representing study registries, funding agencies, institutional compliance and governance units, journals and other scholarly communications venues, and research managers, as well as investigators themselves.

Participants discussed and built consensus around priority challenges?namely incentives in publishing and academic career advancement?and explored mechanisms for enabling more open and complete sharing of research results. The workshop opened with a discussion of how science is organized with a focus on design flaws that result in incomplete reporting, questionable research practices, and ?the file drawer problem? wherein researchers are unable or unwilling to share non-significant or negative results. Speakers Jeremy Weinstein and Scott Williamson of IPL set the stage with an example of an NSF-funded project led by his team who faced major challenges in publishing a paper detailing their experimental research, in large part because they found non-significant results. Their experience led them to begin developing a template for reporting results regardless of their nature within their lab. 

This introduction was followed by a series of panel discussions focused on different sectors or nodes of the scientific ecosystem, and the mechanisms that could be used to facilitate more open sharing of research outputs. Four panels focused on (i) study registries and pre-analysis plans, (ii) legal and institutional compliance, (iii) conventional publication channels (i.e., journals), and (iv) other scholarly communication infrastructure (e.g., preprints archives, repositories, libraries, and newer initiatives). A subsequent session visualizing and mapping the ecosystem led into breakout groups and a facilitated group discussion during which participants deliberated and began building consensus on priority issues and possible interventions and policies to address them. The figure below is an updated representation of the mapping exercise that helped situate these conversations.

The workshop yielded several outputs that are supporting the planning of an implementation phase. A body of constructive suggestions and feedback from participants has informed a proposal to the scientific community of a framework integrating low-cost interventions that are incentive-compatible to researchers. Developed by the workshop organizers and several participants, this proposal will be shared shortly in a synthesis paper titled ?Unlocking the File Drawer: A RARE Framework to Normalize Complete Reporting? by lead authors by PI Edward Miguel and David Laitin, as well as co-authors Ala? Alrabahbah, Aleksandar Bogdanoski, Sean Grant, Katherine Hoeberling, Cecilia Hyunjung Mo, Don Moore, Jeremy Weinstein, and Scott Williamson. This paper is the beginning of a concrete plan for further collaboration, testing, and scaling of a framework to Report All Results Efficiently (RARE). RARE is the result of several months of reflection and deliberation about how to advocate for and implement the key ideas discussed at the workshop. It calls for a coordinated effort on the parts of researchers, study registries, institutional review boards (IRBs), funders, and journals to commit, incentivize, and enable researchers to report fully and publicly the results of their funded research.

Over the next year, the team hopes to identify partners within one or more of these nodes with the interest and capacity to test one of the following interventions, or to collaborate in proposing alternatives:  (a) providing space for results reporting in registries and supporting researchers in using them, (b) integrating into IRB protocols plans to publicly report results, (c) requiring grant applicants to confirm whether results from previously funded grants have been reported publicly, (d) normalizing the integration of funding for research support staff in granting to help investigators fulfill reporting requirements, (e) asking authors submitting to journals to verify that complete results have been reported publicly, and (f) exploring adaptations of this framework for observational research.

The successful implementation of the RARE framework would have several impacts on society beyond reducing publication bias and questionable research practices. It would introduce efficiencies and improved accountability into the prioritization and funding of research projects. It would increase access to the outputs of scientific research for researchers and the public alike, accelerating the production of knowledge and giving analysts a more complete body of evidence on which to base policy decisions. And finally, it would provide alternative mechanisms for publishing research, which could help level the playing field of academic career advancement. More information, including an agenda, list of participants, and video recordings of the workshop?s sessions can be found at: https://www.bitss.org/events/workshop-unlocking-the-file-drawer/.
